 002: Code for rotating spherical harmonics expansions by the method described in:

static PyObject *__pyx_pw_6lie_learn_15Representations_3SO3_14pinchon_hoggan_14pinchon_hoggan_1apply_z_rotation_block_batch(PyObject *__pyx_self, PyObject *__pyx_args, PyObject *__pyx_kwds); /*proto*/
static char __pyx_doc_6lie_learn_15Representations_3SO3_14pinchon_hoggan_14pinchon_hoggan_apply_z_rotation_block_batch[] = "\n    Apply the rotation about the z-axis by angle angles[i, j] to the vector\n    X[:,i] for all i,j. The vectors in X are assumed to be in the basis of real\n    block spherical harmonics, corresponding to the irreps.\n\n    //The z-axis rotation matrix (called X(angle) in the P&H paper) has a special\n    //form with cosines of different frequencies on the diagonal and sines on the\n    //anti-diagonal. This matrix is very sparse, so constructing it explicitly is\n    //very inefficient. This function applies a batch of such 'cross' matrices,\n    //represented implicitly by the corresponding angles, to a batch of vectors,\n    //without explicitly constructing the matrices.\n\n    Args:\n      angles: matrix of angles, shape (num_data, num_angles)\n      irreps: a list of irrep weights (integers)\n      l_max: an integer that is equal to np.max(irreps)\n      X: matrix to be rotated, shape (dim, num_data)\n      X_out: matrix where output will be stored, shape (dim, num_data, num_angles)\n\n    Returns:\n      X_out: matrix of shape (dim, num_data, num_angles), such that the\n             vector X_out[:, i, j] is the rotation of X[:,i] by angles[i, j].\n    ";

 055:                                  np.ndarray[FLOAT_TYPE_t, ndim=2] X,
 056:                                  np.ndarray[INT_TYPE_t, ndim=1] irreps,
 057:                                  np.ndarray[INT_TYPE_t, ndim=1] c2b,
 058:                                  int l_max,
 059:                                  np.ndarray[FLOAT_TYPE_t, ndim=3] X_out):
 060:     """
 061:     Apply the rotation about the z-axis by angle angles[i, j] to the vector
 062:     X[:,i] for all i,j. The vectors in X are assumed to be in the basis of real
 063:     block spherical harmonics, corresponding to the irreps.
 064: 
 065:     //The z-axis rotation matrix (called X(angle) in the P&H paper) has a special
 066:     //form with cosines of different frequencies on the diagonal and sines on the
 067:     //anti-diagonal. This matrix is very sparse, so constructing it explicitly is
 068:     //very inefficient. This function applies a batch of such 'cross' matrices,
 069:     //represented implicitly by the corresponding angles, to a batch of vectors,
 070:     //without explicitly constructing the matrices.
 071: 
 072:     Args:
 073:       angles: matrix of angles, shape (num_data, num_angles)
 074:       irreps: a list of irrep weights (integers)
 075:       l_max: an integer that is equal to np.max(irreps)
 076:       X: matrix to be rotated, shape (dim, num_data)
 077:       X_out: matrix where output will be stored, shape (dim, num_data, num_angles)
 078: 
 079:     Returns:
 080:       X_out: matrix of shape (dim, num_data, num_angles), such that the
 081:              vector X_out[:, i, j] is the rotation of X[:,i] by angles[i, j].
 082:     """
 083: 
 084:     cdef int irrep_ind    # Index into the IRREPS2 matrix
 085:     cdef int irrep        # The irrep weight
 086:     cdef int center       # The index of the center element (l=0) of current irrep
 087:     cdef int offset       # The offset of the current coordinate from the center
 088:     cdef int abs_offset   # The absolute value of the offset
 089:     cdef int offset_sign  # The sign of the offset
 090:     #cdef int l_max = np.max(irreps)
 091: 
+092:     cdef int Xs0 = X.shape[0]

+093:     cdef int Xs1 = X.shape[1]

 151:                             np.ndarray[FLOAT_TYPE_t, ndim=2] X,
 152:                             np.ndarray[INT_TYPE_t, ndim=1] irreps,
 153:                             int l_max,
 154:                             np.ndarray[FLOAT_TYPE_t, ndim=3] X_out):
 155:     """
 156:     Apply the rotation about the z-axis by angle angles[i, j] to the vector
 157:     X[:,i] for all i,j. The vectors in X are assumed to be in the basis of real
 158:     centered spherical harmonics, corresponding to the irreps.
 159: 
 160:     The z-axis rotation matrix (called X(angle) in the P&H paper) has a special
 161:     form with cosines of different frequencies on the diagonal and sines on the
 162:     anti-diagonal. This matrix is very sparse, so constructing it explicitly is
 163:     very inefficient. This function applies a batch of such 'cross' matrices,
 164:     represented implicitly by the corresponding angles, to a batch of vectors,
 165:     without explicitly constructing the matrices.
 166: 
 167:     Args:
 168:       angles: matrix of angles, shape (num_data, num_angles)
 169:       irreps: a list of irrep weights (integers)
 170:       l_max: an integer that is equal to np.max(irreps)
 171:       X: matrix to be rotated, shape (dim, num_data)
 172:       X_out: matrix where output will be stored, shape (dim, num_data, num_angles)
 173: 
 174:     Returns:
 175:       X_out: matrix of shape (dim, num_data, num_angles), such that the
 176:              vector X_out[:, i, j] is the rotation of X[:,i] by angles[i, j].
 177:     """
 178: 
 179:     cdef int irrep_ind    # Index into the IRREPS2 matrix
 180:     cdef int irrep        # The irrep weight
 181:     cdef int center       # The index of the center element (l=0) of current irrep
 182:     cdef int offset       # The offset of the current coordinate from the center
 183:     cdef int abs_offset   # The absolute value of the offset
 184:     cdef int offset_sign  # The sign of the offset
 185:     #cdef int l_max = np.max(irreps)
 186: 
+187:     cdef int Xs0 = X.shape[0]

+188:     cdef int Xs1 = X.shape[1]

 189:     cdef int Cs2

 242:     """
 243:     Multiply the Pinchon-Hoggan J matrix by a matrix X.
 244: 
 245:     This function uses the J matrix in the Pinchon-Hoggan block-basis. In this basis, the J-matrix a block matrix
 246:     with 4 blocks.
 247: 
 248:     :param X: numpy array of shape (dim, N) where dim is the total dimension of the representation and N is the number
 249:      of vectors to be multiplied by J.

 389: # def apply_rotation_batch(g, X, irreps, J_sparse=None, X_out=None, inv=False):
 390: #     """
 391: #     Apply the rotations g[:, i, j] to vectors X[:, i] (for all j).
 392: #     The cols of X are assumed to be in the basis of real spherical harmonics,
 393: #     corresponding to the given irreps.
 394: #
 395: #     By using the factorized representation of g, this method achieves
 396: #     computational complexity of O(l_max) instead of O(l_max^3),
 397: #     which one would get by explicitly constructing the rotation matrix.
 398: #
 399: #     Args:
 400: #       g:
 401: #       X:
 402: #       irreps:
 403: #       J_sparse:
 404: #       X_out:
 405: #
 406: #     returns:
 407: #       X_out:
 408: #     """

 410: #         J_sparse = make_sparse_J(irreps)
 411: #
 412: #     out_shape = X.shape + (g.shape[-1],)

 414: #     if inv:
 415: #         X_out = apply_z_rotation_batch(-g[0], X, irreps, X_out=X_out)
 416: #         X_out_flat = X_out.reshape(X_out.shape[0], X_out.shape[1] * X_out.shape[2])
 417: #         X_temp = J_sparse.dot(X_out_flat)
 418: #         apply_z_rotation(-g[1].flatten(), X_temp, irreps, X_out=X_out_flat)

 420: #         X_temp = J_sparse.dot(X_out_flat)
 421: #         apply_z_rotation(-g[2].flatten(), X_temp, irreps, X_out=X_out_flat)
 422: #     else:
 423: #         X_out = apply_z_rotation_batch(g[2], X, irreps, X_out=X_out)

 433: #
 434: # def apply_z_rotation_batch(angles, X, irreps, X_out=None):
 435: #     """
 436: #     Apply the rotation about the z-axis by angle angles[i, j] to the vector
 437: #     X[:,i] for all i,j. The vectors in X are assumed to be in the basis of real
 438: #     spherical harmonics, corresponding to the irreps.
 439: #
 440: #     The z-axis rotation matrix (called X(angle) in the P&H paper) has a special
 441: #     form with cosines of different frequencies on the diagonal and sines on the
 442: #     anti-diagonal. This matrix is very sparse, so constructing it explicitly is
 443: #     very inefficient. This function applies a batch of such 'cross' matrices,
 444: #     represented implicitly by the corresponding angles, to a batch of vectors,
 445: #     without explicitly constructing the matrices.
 446: #
 447: #     Args:
 448: #       angles: matrix of angles, shape (num_data, num_angles)
 449: #       irreps: a list of irrep weights (integers)
 450: #       X: matrix to be rotated, shape (dim, num_data)
 451: #
 452: #     Returns:
 453: #       X_out: matrix of shape (dim, num_data, num_angles), such that the
 454: #              vector X_out[:, i, j] is the rotation of X[:,i] by angles[i, j].
 455: #     """
 456: #
 457: #     # The c-code assumes irreps is a numpy array, so make sure it is
 458: #     irreps = np.array(irreps)
 459: #     angles = np.atleast_2d(angles)
 460: #
 461: #     X = np.atleast_2d(X.T).T  # shape (dim,) -> (dim, 1); (dim, n) -> (dim, n)
 462: #     out_shape = (X.shape[0], X.shape[1], angles.shape[1])
 463: #
 464: #     # Check that the irrep dimensions sum to the right dimensionality
 465: #     assert (2 * irreps + 1).sum() == X.shape[0], "Invalid irrep dimensions"
 466: #     assert angles.shape[0] == X.shape[1]
 467: #
 468: #     if X_out is None:
 469: #         X_out = np.empty((X.shape[0], X.shape[1], angles.shape[1]))
 470: #         #if angles.size == 1:
 471: #         #    X_out = np.empty_like(X)
 472: #         #else:
 473: #         #    X_out = np.empty(X.shape + (angles.shape[1],))
 474: #
 475: #     assert X_out.shape == (X.shape[0], X.shape[1], angles.shape[1]), "Invalid shape for X_out"
 476: #     #assert angles.size == 1 or X_out.shape == X.shape + (angles.shape[1],), "Invalid shape for X_out"
 477: #
 478: #     l_max = np.max(irreps)
 479: #     C = np.cos(angles[None, :, :] * np.arange(l_max + 1)[:, None, None])
 480: #     S = np.sin(angles[None, :, :] * np.arange(l_max + 1)[:, None, None])
 481: #
 482: #     code="""
 483: #     int irrep_ind;   // Index into the IRREPS2 matrix
 484: #     int irrep;       // The irrep weight
 485: #     int center;      // The index of the center element (l=0) of current irrep
 486: #     int offset;      // The offset of the current coordinate from the center
 487: #     int abs_offset;  // The absolute value of the offset
 488: #     int offset_sign; // The sign of the offset
 489: #
 490: #     for(int vec = 0; vec < NX[1]; vec++){ // For every vector to be transformed
 491: #        irrep_ind = 0; // Start at the first irrep
 492: #        irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get the weight from the array
 493: #        center = irrep;
 494: #        for(int coord = 0; coord < NX[0]; coord++) { // For every coordinate of this vector
 495: #           offset = coord - center;
 496: #           if(offset > irrep) {              // Finished with the current irrep?
 497: #              irrep_ind++;                   // Go to the next irrep
 498: #              irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get its weight from the list
 499: #              center = coord + irrep;        // Compute the new center
 500: #              offset = -irrep;               // equivalent to offset=coord-center;
 501: #           }
 502: #           // Compute the absolute value and sign of the offset
 503: #           abs_offset = offset >= 0 ? offset : -offset;
 504: #           offset_sign = offset >= 0 ? 1 : -1;
 505: #
 506: #           // Loop over every angle in the batch of angles
 507: #           for(int angle_ind=0; angle_ind < NC[2]; angle_ind++) {
 508: #              // Compute the value of the transformed coordinate
 509: #              // Note: we're always adding *two* values, even when offset=0 and hence there is only
 510: #              // one non-zero element in that row. This is not a problem because S2(0, vec) is always 0.
 511: #              X_OUT3(coord, vec, angle_ind) = C3(abs_offset, vec, angle_ind) * X2(coord, vec)
 512: #                              - offset_sign * S3(abs_offset, vec, angle_ind) * X2(center - offset, vec);
 513: #           }
 514: #        }
 515: #     }
 516: #     """
 517: #     inline(code, ['C', 'S', 'irreps', 'X', 'X_out'])
 518: #     return X_out.reshape(*out_shape)
 519: #
 520: #
 521: # def apply_z_rotation(angles, X, irreps, X_out=None):
 522: #     """
 523: #     Apply the rotation about the z-axis by angle angles[i] to the vector
 524: #     X[:,i] for all i. The vectors in X are assumed to be in the basis of real
 525: #     spherical harmonics, corresponding to the irreps.
 526: #
 527: #     The z-axis rotation matrix (called X(angle) in Pinchon-Hoggan) has a special
 528: #     form with cosines of different frequencies on the diagonal and sines on the
 529: #     anti-diagonal. This matrix is very sparse, so constructing it explicitly is
 530: #     very inefficient. This function applies a batch of such 'cross' matrices,
 531: #     represented implicitly by the corresponding angles, to a batch of vectors,
 532: #     without explicitly constructing the matrices.
 533: #     """
 534: #
 535: #     # The c-code assumes irreps is a numpy array, so make sure it is
 536: #     irreps = np.array(irreps)
 537: #
 538: #     # Check that the irrep dimensions sum to the right dimensionality
 539: #     assert (2 * irreps + 1).sum() == X.shape[0], "Invalid irrep dimensions"
 540: #     assert angles.shape[0] == X.shape[1]
 541: #     assert angles.size == X.shape[1]
 542: #
 543: #     if X_out is None:
 544: #         X_out = np.empty_like(X)
 545: #
 546: #     assert X_out.shape == X.shape, "X_out should have the same shape as X"
 547: #
 548: #     l_max = np.max(irreps)
 549: #     C = np.cos(angles[None, ...] * np.arange(l_max + 1)[:, None])
 550: #     S = np.sin(angles[None, ...] * np.arange(l_max + 1)[:, None])
 551: #
 552: #     code_OLD= """
 553: #     int irrep_ind;   // Index into the IRREPS2 matrix
 554: #     int irrep;       // The irrep weight
 555: #     int center;      // The index of the center element (l=0) of the current irrep
 556: #     int offset;      // The offset of the current coordinate from the center
 557: #     int abs_offset;  // The absolute value of the offset
 558: #     int offset_sign; // The sign of the offset
 559: #
 560: #     for(int vec = 0; vec < NX[1]; vec++) { // For every vector to be transformed..
 561: #        irrep_ind = 0; // Start at the first irrep
 562: #        irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get the weight from the array
 563: #        center = irrep;
 564: #        for(int coord = 0; coord < NX[0]; coord++) { // For every coordinate of this vector
 565: #           offset = coord - center;
 566: #           if(offset > irrep) {              // Finished with the current irrep?
 567: #              irrep_ind++;                   // Go to the next irrep
 568: #              irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get its weight from the list
 569: #              center = coord + irrep;        // Compute the new center
 570: #              offset = -irrep;               // equivalent to offset=coord-center;
 571: #           }
 572: #           // Compute the absolute value and sign of the offset
 573: #           abs_offset = offset >= 0 ? offset : -offset;
 574: #           offset_sign = offset >= 0 ? 1 : -1;
 575: #
 576: #           // Compute the value of the transformed coordinate
 577: #           // Note: we're always adding *two* values, even when offset=0 and hence there is only
 578: #           // one non-zero element in that row. This is not a problem because S2(0, vec) is always 0.
 579: #           X_OUT2(coord, vec) = C2(abs_offset, vec) * X2(coord, vec)
 580: #                              - offset_sign * S2(abs_offset, vec) * X2(center - offset, vec);
 581: #        }
 582: #     }
 583: #     """
 584: #
 585: #     # This code has the order of for-loops reversed, and is much faster
 586: #     code="""
 587: #     int irrep_ind;   // Index into the IRREPS2 matrix
 588: #     int irrep;       // The irrep weight
 589: #     int center;      // The index of the center element (l=0) of the current irrep
 590: #     int offset;      // The offset of the current coordinate from the center
 591: #     int abs_offset;  // The absolute value of the offset
 592: #     int offset_sign; // The sign of the offset
 593: #
 594: #     irrep_ind = 0; // Start at the first irrep
 595: #     irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get the weight from the array
 596: #     center = irrep;
 597: #     for(int coord = 0; coord < NX[0]; coord++) { // For every coordinate of this vector
 598: #
 599: #        offset = coord - center;
 600: #        if(offset > irrep) {              // Finished with the current irrep?
 601: #           irrep_ind++;                   // Go to the next irrep
 602: #           irrep = IRREPS2(irrep_ind, 0); // Get its weight from the list
 603: #           center = coord + irrep;        // Compute the new center
 604: #           offset = -irrep;               // equivalent to offset=coord-center;
 605: #        }
 606: #        // Compute the absolute value and sign of the offset
 607: #        abs_offset = offset >= 0 ? offset : -offset;
 608: #        offset_sign = offset >= 0 ? 1 : -1;
 609: #
 610: #        for(int vec = 0; vec < NX[1]; vec++) { // For every vector to be transformed..
 611: #
 612: #           // Compute the value of the transformed coordinate
 613: #           // Note: we're always adding *two* values, even when offset=0 and hence there is only
 614: #           // one non-zero element in that row. This is not a problem because S2(0, vec) is always 0.
 615: #           X_OUT2(coord, vec) = C2(abs_offset, vec) * X2(coord, vec)
 616: #                              - offset_sign * S2(abs_offset, vec) * X2(center - offset, vec);
 617: #        }
 618: #     }
 619: #     """
 620: #     inline(code_OLD, ['C', 'S', 'irreps', 'X', 'X_out'])
 621: #     return X_out
